title: Daily Standup & Collaboration
description: Master the Daily Standup ceremony—15-minute timebox, 3 questions framework, parking lot technique, and team synchronization (not status reporting).
objectives: Recognize Daily Standup as a TEAM synchronization event (not PM/Scrum Master status meeting)
Apply the 3 Questions framework: What did I do? What will I do? What blockers?
Understand Daily Standup is timeboxed to 15 minutes (regardless of team size)
Use parking lot technique to defer detailed technical discussions
Recognize Scrum Master role as facilitator and impediment remover

screens.headline: Daily standup turns into 45-minute interrogation. Morgan asks detailed questions. Maya and Devon debate frameworks. Alex says: 'This isn't how standup works.' Who's right?

items.label: Correct
items.detail: Team in circle, 15 minutes, parking lot board visible

dialogue.text: Daily Standup is NOT a status meeting for the PM or Product Owner. It's a TEAM synchronization event—15 minutes, 3 questions, identify blockers. Detailed discussions go in the parking lot.

screens.learningHook: Learn what Daily Standup's TRUE purpose is, the 3 questions, 15-minute timebox, and parking lot technique.

screens.title: Daily Standup Best Practices
screens.instructions: Identify correct standup practices, distinguish team synchronization from status reporting, and apply parking lot technique.

scenarios.title: Morgan's Interrogation
description: Maya: 'Yesterday I finalized Thai basil recipe. Today plating design. No blockers.'
Morgan interrupts: 'Wait—why Thai basil over holy basil? Explain your reasoning.'

questions.question: What is the PRIMARY purpose of Daily Standup in Scrum?

options.text: Status reporting to Product Owner and Scrum Master
Team synchronization: share progress, identify blockers
Scrum Master assigns tasks and tracks progress

feedback.correct: Daily Standup is TEAM synchronization—members share with EACH OTHER to coordinate work. PM/PO can attend and listen, but team doesn't 'report upward.'
feedback.incorrect: Standup is for TEAM synchronization, not status reporting. Team talks TO EACH OTHER, not TO authority figures.

scenarios.title: React vs Vue Debate
description: Devon: 'I'm deciding between React and Vue.js.'
Maya: 'I think React is better.' Devon: 'But Vue has gentler learning curve.'

options.text: Let them continue—technical decisions are important
Use parking lot: 'Great topic—discuss React vs Vue after standup. Let's move on.'
Stop standup and resolve framework decision with whole team
Tell them technical topics aren't relevant to standup

feedback.correct: Parking lot technique: note the detailed topic, defer to AFTER standup with interested members only. Keeps standup focused, timeboxed, respectful of everyone's time.
feedback.incorrect: Detailed discussions don't belong in standup. Use parking lot: defer to after standup with interested members.

scenarios.title: Standup Duration
description: Taylor: 'I thought duration depends on team size. We're 5 people—10 minutes?'

questions.question: What is the correct timebox for Daily Standup?

options.text: 10 min for small teams, 15 for medium, 20 for large
15 minutes (fixed, regardless of team size or sprint length)
Team decides based on their needs

feedback.correct: Daily Standup is ALWAYS 15 minutes—regardless of team size (5 vs 10) or sprint length (1-week vs 4-week). This is a Scrum RULE, non-negotiable.
feedback.incorrect: 15 minutes is the Scrum rule for Daily Standup—fixed regardless of team size or sprint length. Enforce it ruthlessly.

purpose: SYNCHRONIZE work: Team shares current state
IDENTIFY blockers: Surface obstacles for Scrum Master
TEAM ownership: Members talk TO EACH OTHER
whatItIsNot: NOT status meeting for PM/Product Owner
NOT optional or flexible on time

questions.text: What did I do YESTERDAY (or since last standup)?
What will I do TODAY (or until next standup)?
What BLOCKERS or IMPEDIMENTS do I have?

content.benefit: Keep standup BRIEF (1-2 min per person), FOCUSED, and ACTIONABLE.

timebox.why: Forces brevity, respects time, maintains energy

parkingLot.definition: Note detailed topics, defer to AFTER standup
parkingLot.why: Respects time, keeps standup focused, prevents derailment

content.pmbokRef: PMBOK 7th Ed page 35; Agile Practice Guide page 41

content.technique: Compromise: Find time slightly inconvenient for all but acceptable
content.when: Distributed teams across time zones (constraint beyond team control)
content.example: Maya (SF/PST) + Devon (NY/EST): 10am EST = 7am PST—workable for both

correct.text: I see now—standup isn't MY status meeting. The team synchronizes with EACH OTHER. I can listen and follow up offline. 15 minutes, focused on blockers, team ownership.
Parking lot keeps standup efficient. Detailed discussions happen after standup with relevant people. Everyone else gets their time back.

screens.title: Distributed Team Standup
screens.context: 8 members across 4 time zones: NYC (EST), Denver (MST), SF (PST), London (GMT). Challenges: time zones, some want async standup, one wants 30-minute standup.

questions.question: How should Alex handle time zone conflicts?

options.text: Let team vote on standup time
Use COMPROMISE: find time slightly inconvenient for all but acceptable
Async (Slack) to avoid time zone hassles
Synchronous (live video) for real-time team coordination
15 minutes (fixed timebox regardless of team size)

screens.title: Daily Standup Mastery
screens.summary: Daily Standup is TEAM synchronization (not status meeting), uses 3 questions, 15-minute timebox, parking lot for detailed discussions, and Scrum Master removes impediments.
takeaways: Daily Standup = TEAM synchronization, NOT status reporting to PM/PO
3 Questions: What did I do? What will I do? What blockers?
15 minutes ALWAYS (fixed regardless of team size or sprint length)
Parking lot: defer detailed discussions to after standup
Scrum Master facilitates and removes impediments (not assigns tasks)

characterClosing.text: I started treating standup as MY interrogation session. Alex showed me: standup is TEAM synchronization. Team talks to team, not to me. I can listen and follow up offline. Way more efficient.
